text: Symptoms: Hoarseness {unilateral), aphonia and stridor {bilateral). Evaluation: Vocal cord function can be evaluated by Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Palsy laryngoscopy immediately following “deep extubation” if necessary. Management: Reintubation and wound exploration may be required if vocal cords are immobile. Risk: Can compress the trachea, obstructing the airway, particularly in patients with tracheomalacia. Wound Hematomas Management: Immedliate treatment includes opening the neck wound, evacuating the clot, and reassessing the need for reintubation. Anesthesia personnel must be prepared to open the surgical wound if the surgeon is unavailable.
